speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: SCENE VII. The forest.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: A table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and Lords like outlaws

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I think he be transform'd into a beast;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: For I can no where find him like a man.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: My lord, he is but even now gone hence:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here was he merry, hearing of a song.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: If he, compact of jars, grow musical,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go, seek him: tell him I would speak with him.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Enter JAQUES

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He saves my labour by his own approach.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That your poor friends must woo your company?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What, you look merrily!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A fool, a fool! I met a fool i' the forest,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A motley fool; a miserable world!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: As I do live by food, I met a fool

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And rail'd on Lady Fortune in good terms,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In good set terms and yet a motley fool.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: 'Good morrow, fool,' quoth I. 'No, sir,' quoth he,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: 'Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune:'

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then he drew a dial from his poke,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Thus we may see,' quoth he, 'how the world wags:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: 'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And after one hour more 'twill be eleven;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And thereby hangs a tale.' When I did hear

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The motley fool thus moral on the time,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: My lungs began to crow like chanticleer,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That fools should be so deep-contemplative,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And I did laugh sans intermission

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: An hour by his dial. O noble fool!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What fool is this?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And says, if ladies be but young and fair,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They have the gift to know it: and in his brain,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: After a voyage, he hath strange places cramm'd

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With observation, the which he vents

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I am ambitious for a motley coat.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou shalt have one.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: It is my only suit;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Provided that you weed your better judgments

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Of all opinion that grows rank in them

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That I am wise. I must have liberty

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Withal, as large a charter as the wind,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To blow on whom I please; for so fools have;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And they that are most galled with my folly,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The 'why' is plain as way to parish church:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: He that a fool doth very wisely hit

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Doth very foolishly, although he smart,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Not to seem senseless of the bob: if not,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The wise man's folly is anatomized

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Even by the squandering glances of the fool.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Invest me in my motley; give me leave

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To speak my mind, and I will through and through

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Cleanse the foul body of the infected world,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: If they will patiently receive my medicine.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What, for a counter, would I do but good?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Most mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: For thou thyself hast been a libertine,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As sensual as the brutish sting itself;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And all the embossed sores and headed evils,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That thou with licence of free foot hast caught,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, who cries out on pride,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That can therein tax any private party?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Till that the weary very means do ebb?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What woman in the city do I name,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: When that I say the city-woman bears

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Who can come in and say that I mean her,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: When such a one as she such is her neighbour?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Or what is he of basest function

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That says his bravery is not of my cost,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His folly to the mettle of my speech?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There then; how then? what then? Let me see wherein

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: My tongue hath wrong'd him: if it do him right,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Then he hath wrong'd himself; if he be free,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why then my taxing like a wild-goose flies,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Unclaim'd of any man. But who comes here?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO, with his sword drawn

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Forbear, and eat no more.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, I have eat none yet.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Nor shalt not, till necessity be served.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Of what kind should this cock come of?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Art thou thus bolden'd, man, by thy distress,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Or else a rude despiser of good manners,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That in civility thou seem'st so empty?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of smooth civility: yet am I inland bred

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And know some nurture. But forbear, I say:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: He dies that touches any of this fruit

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Till I and my affairs are answered.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What would you have? Your gentleness shall force

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: More than your force move us to gentleness.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I almost die for food; and let me have it.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thought that all things had been savage here;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And therefore put I on the countenance

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of stern commandment. But whate'er you are

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That in this desert inaccessible,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Under the shade of melancholy boughs,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever you have look'd on better days,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever been where bells have knoll'd to church,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever sat at any good man's feast,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Let gentleness my strong enforcement be:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: True is it that we have seen better days,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And have with holy bell been knoll'd to church

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Of drops that sacred pity hath engender'd:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And therefore sit you down in gentleness

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And take upon command what help we have

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That to your wanting may be minister'd.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then but forbear your food a little while,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And give it food. There is an old poor man,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who after me hath many a weary step

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Limp'd in pure love: till he be first sufficed,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Oppress'd with two weak evils, age and hunger,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will not touch a bit.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go find him out,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And we will nothing waste till you return.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: This wide and universal theatre

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Presents more woeful pageants than the scene

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Wherein we play in.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: All the world's a stage,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And all the men and women merely players:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They have their exits and their entrances;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And one man in his time plays many parts,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then the whining school-boy, with his satchel

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And shining morning face, creeping like snail

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Seeking the bubble reputation

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In fair round belly with good capon lined,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Full of wise saws and modern instances;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Turning again toward childish treble, pipes

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That ends this strange eventful history,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Is second childishness and mere oblivion,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Re-enter ORLANDO, with ADAM

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Welcome. Set down your venerable burthen,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And let him feed.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thank you most for him.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: So had you need:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Welcome; fall to: I will not trouble you

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As yet, to question you about your fortunes.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Give us some music; and, good cousin, sing.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Blow, blow, thou winter wind.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thou art not so unkind

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As man's ingratitude;

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thy tooth is not so keen,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Because thou art not seen,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Although thy breath be rude.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Heigh-ho! sing, heigh-ho! unto the green holly:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Then, heigh-ho, the holly!

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: This life is most jolly.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: That dost not bite so nigh

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As benefits forgot:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Though thou the waters warp,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thy sting is not so sharp

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As friend remember'd not.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Heigh-ho! sing,  and c.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As you have whisper'd faithfully you were,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And as mine eye doth his effigies witness

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Most truly limn'd and living in your face,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Be truly welcome hither: I am the duke

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That loved your father: the residue of your fortune,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go to my cave and tell me. Good old man,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou art right welcome as thy master is.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And let me all your fortunes understand.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Exeunt
